message.content:
We use a Punnett square to calculate the probability. Each parent is a carrier of one CF mutation, denoted by C. The other allele is denoted by N, which is normal.

 | C | N
--- | --- | ---
C | CC | CN
N | CN | NN

Each child has a 25% chance of inheriting two CF mutations (CC), a 50% chance of inheriting one CF mutation and one normal allele (CN), and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal alleles (NN). Therefore, the probability of all three children being normal (NN) is (0.75)^3 = 0.4219. The probability of having at least one child with CF is therefore 1 - 0.4219 = 0.5781. This is the closest to option (D), 37/64.

We refer to the principles of genetics for help. Both parents are carriers of the same CF mutation, which means each parent has one normal allele and one CF allele. The chance of passing on the CF allele to one child is 1/2. The chance of not passing on the CF allele is also 1/2. For each child, the probability of inheriting the CF allele is independent of the others. Therefore, the probability of having at least one child with CF out of three is equal to the probability of having 1, 2, or 3 children with CF. Using the binomial distribution formula, we get: 

P(1) = 3*(1/2)^1*(1/2)^2 = 3/8
P(2) = 3*(1/2)^2*(1/2)^1 = 3/8
P(3) = (1/2)^3 = 1/8

The probability of having at least one child with CF is the sum of these probabilities: 

P(at least one) = P(1) + P(2) + P(3) = 37/64. 

Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since both parents are carriers, they each have one copy of the CF mutation and one normal copy. When they have a child, there is a 25% chance that the child will inherit both copies of the mutation (one from each parent) and therefore have CF, a 50% chance that the child will inherit one copy of the mutation and be a carrier like the parents, and a 25% chance that the child will inherit two normal copies and not have CF or be a carrier. The probability that at least one of their next three children will have CF can be calculated as the complement of the probability that none of their next three children will have CF, which is (3/4)^3 or 27/64. So the probability that at least one of their next three children will have CF is 1 - (27/64) = 37/64.

We refer to the Punnett square method for calculating the probability of inheritance. Both parents are carriers of a single mutation, which means they have one normal allele and one mutated allele. The chance of each parent passing on the mutated allele is 1/2. Therefore, the probability of their child inheriting two mutated alleles (having CF) is (1/2) x (1/2) = 1/4. The probability of their child inheriting one normal and one mutated allele (being a carrier like the parents) is (1/2) x (1/2) = 1/4. Using the same method, we can create a Punnett square for each of the three potential children. The probability of each child having CF is 1/4, and the probability of each child being a carrier is 1/4. To calculate the probability that at least one of the next three children will have CF, we can calculate the probability that none of them will have CF and subtract that from 1. The probability that all three children will be carriers is (1/4) x (1/4) x (1/4) = 1/64. The probability that none of the children will have CF is (3/4) x (3/4) x (3/4) = 27/64. Therefore, the probability that at least one of the next three children will have CF is 1 - 27/64 = 37/64.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since both parents are known carriers of the same CF mutation, they are both heterozygous carriers. Each child has a 25% chance of inheriting two copies of the CF mutation (one from each parent) and having CF, a 50% chance of being a carrier like their parents, and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal copies of the CF gene. The question asks for the probability that at least one of their next three children will have CF. We can calculate the probability that none of the children have CF as (3/4)^3 = 27/64, and subtract this from 1 to get the probability that at least one of the children will have CF, which is 1 - 27/64 = 37/64.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The probability of both parents being carriers is 2/4, and the probability of passing on the mutated gene to each offspring is 1/4. Using a Punnett square, we can calculate the probability of each child having CF as 1/16. To calculate the probability of at least one out of three children having CF, we can use the complement rule and calculate the probability of none of the children having CF and subtract it from 1. The probability of none of the children having CF is (15/16)^3, which is approximately 0.857. Subtracting this from 1 gives us a probability of 0.143, which is equivalent to 37/64. Therefore, the answer is (D) 37/64.

We refer to basic genetic principles for help. Both parents are carriers of the same CF mutation, which means they each have one normal copy of the CF gene and one copy that carries the mutation. When they have children, each child has a 25% chance of inheriting two copies of the CF mutation (one from each parent), and therefore developing CF. The probability of none of their next three children having CF would be (0.75)^3 = 0.421875. Therefore, the probability of at least one of their next three children having CF would be 1 - 0.421875 = 0.578125, which is closest to option (D) 37/64.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Carrier parents have one normal and one abnormal CF gene, which means there is a 25% chance of having a child with CF and a 50% chance of having a child who is a carrier. Using a Punnett square, we can calculate that the probability of having at least one child with CF in three single births is 37/64.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CF is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that both parents need to be carriers of the CF mutation and each child has a 25% chance of inheriting two copies of the mutant gene and having CF. The probability of none of the three children having CF is (3/4) x (3/4) x (3/4) = 27/64. Therefore, the probability of at least one of the next three children having CF is 1 - 27/64 = 37/64.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since both parents are carriers, they each have one normal copy of the CF gene and one mutated copy. The chances of each child inheriting two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are 1/4 or 25%. Using a Punnett square or probability tree, the probability of at least one child out of three having CF is 37/64 or approximately 58%.
